div1.p: Barker lists additional Lazear references. The letter includes autograph notes by Hench on the Lazear memorial inscription at Johns Hopkins University.

div1.head: Letter from Lewellys F. Barker to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, August 1, 1940
div1.p:
Supplementing my recent letter regarding
Dr. Lazear, I may say that the account of Dr. Lazear
in H. A. Kelly's “Walter Reed and Yellow Fever”
(N. 7, 1907), p. 281 is very good and includes a copy of
a photograph of him (opposite page 282).

In the Johns Hopkins Hospital Bulletin, 1904,
XV, p. 387, the unveiling of the tablet to Dr. Lazear is
described (remarks by W. Osler, J. Carroll and W. S.
Thayer); a picture of the tablet is to be found on p. 389
(the inscription was written by President Eliot of
Harvard University).
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, (signed) Lewellys F. Barker Note Truby
Truby said that
he got Lazear's
note books.!
See Carrolls version of Lazears illness & death
“Before his removal (to the yellow fever isolation camp)
he turned over to me his notes covering all the attempts
in mosquito inoculation & told me of his own
experience of what he had made no record” (it being
better at Las Animas Hosp).
LM
In memory of
Jesse William Lazear
Born 2 May 1866 at Baltimore
Graduated in arts at
The Johns Hopkins University in 1892
In 1895-96 Assistant President Physician
in the Johns Hopkins Hospital
Member of the Yellow Fever Commission in 1900
with the Rank of Acting Assistant Surgeon
He died of Yellow Fever at Quemados Cuba
25 September 1900
With more than the courage & devotion of the soldier
he risked and lost his life to show how an
fearful pestilence is communicated & how its
ravages may be prevented.
Photo tablet on p 389
